results.title: NBA Jam 99 for Game Boy Color
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd and Torus Games
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, manual, registration card, consumer information booklet and Nintendo Power advert in cardboard box
results.brief_description: NBA Jam 99 employs the two-on-two arcade gameplay of that series is known for. This game is similar in gameplay and graphics to NBA Jam Tournament Edition, which was created earlier by the same developer, but with updated colour graphics and animations, more modes, and updated teams and players. Game modes include playing a single game, a full season, playoffs and a practice mode. All 29 NBA teams of the 1998-99 season are included, with five star players per team, each with their unique skills. In fitting with the game’s arcade style, abilities include being able to control both players on a team, power-ups, hot spots where bonus points are scored, juice mode for accelerated gameplay and more.

results.title: Warlords for Mac
results.material_description: Floppy disk videogame. Two 3 1/2 inch floppy disks, colour map, product registration card, subscription card, catalogue and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Warlords is set in the midst of the battle to control the Kingdom of Illuria. The player is put in control one of eight budding empires: The Sirians, Storm Giants, Grey Dwarves, Orcs of Kor, Elvallie, Horse Lords, Selentines, or Lord Bane. Each group has their strengths and weaknesses. The other clans are either controlled by the computer or by another player via hot seat play. The game proceeds on a turn-by-turn basis, with each player issuing commands such as to move units, attack the opposition, order cities to accrue gold, build more units or instruct their heroes to explore Illuria and complete quests before passing the turn to the next player. The game is won once a player has conquered at least half of the kingdom’s eighty cities.

results.title: International Cricket for NES
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge, cartridge sleeve and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description:
International Cricket is one of the only Nintendo Entertainment System (NES) games designed specifically for the Australian market. Melbourne-based Beam Software recreated the cricket pitch in pixels for this iconic game, which simulates a One Day International match and is playable by one to six people, in either single games or round-robin style contests.

Players can bat, bowl and choose to play as big-name cricketers of the day… sort of. Beam Software didn’t get the licenses to use real players, but if you squint hard enough at the character called H. Mervin, you can imagine it’s Merv Hughes.

The game’s AI was notoriously easy to predict but the game’s lack of difficulty didn’t dampen its popularity. Beam Software was also a little difficult to predict – despite working with Nintendo, they cheekily hid images of Sonic the Hedgehog in the game, who was the mascot of rival Sega.

results.title: Balls of Steel for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM in CD jewel case with insert and manual
results.brief_description:
Balls of Steel is a top-down pinball computer game that features five fully-animated pinball tables, each with its own theme, missions, and special bonuses. One of the tables is themed on Duke Nukem, a franchise that Balls of Steel’s publisher, Apogee Software, developed. This tie-in continues to Duke Nukem series itself, where the pinball game appears in several releases.

Balls of Steel plays on a top-down scrolling screen, with an animated dot matrix display at the bottom mimicking the displays of actual pinball tables. As with its real-life counterpart, it shows the player score and animated graphics. Each table can also be viewed in its entirety. High scores are awarded with a “powerball” bonus mode, and could be posted on the “WorldScores” website for a global ranking, although this feature has since been discontinued.

results.title: Dirt Track Racing for PC
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM, CD envelope, install instructions in cardboard box
results.brief_description: In Dirt Track Racing, the player controls a vehicle in a race around oval or figure-eight dirt tracks. The game features three classes of cars - stock, pro stock, and late model - which can be enhanced with high performance parts. The game allows you to either play one race or go through a career mode where the player starts with next to nothing and slowly accumulates more money and better cars through winning races and gaining sponsors. The player can also race up to 10 people online.

results.title: Stargate for SNES
results.creator_credit: Acclaim Entertainment Ltd, Tantalus Media and Probe Software
results.brief_description: This action platform side-scroller set in the sci-fi universe of Stargate has the player rescuing the slaves of Abydos, defeating the evil villain Ra and getting his team back to Earth using the Stargate device. Most missions involve finding people or items in different locations, while fending off enemies with an upgradable machine gun and grenades. In addition, two missions has the player engaging in plane dogfights in one of Ra’s flying gliders. While the overall mission is to defeat Ra, seven bomb pieces and seven hieroglyphs must be collected beforehand or the player will lose the game even if they defeat Ra.

results.title: WipEout 2097 for Sega Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description: WipEout 2097 is set four decades after its predecessor. The F3600 anti-gravity racing competition from the first game has been replaced by an even faster and more dangerous tournament: the F5000 AG league. The racing and weapon use gameplay from the original WipEout remains the same. The main modes from have also returned, but with the addition of a new Challenge Modes. Completing challenges in this mode rewards the player with faster race speeds, new tracks, and new vehicles.

results.title: Star Wars Yoda Stories for Game Boy Color
results.creator_credit: THQ, Lucasfilm, Ltd. and Torus Games
results.material_description: Cartridge videogame. Cartridge and manual in cardboard box
results.brief_description: Despite being based off of the Star Wars universe, Star Wars: Yoda Stories lacks a central plot or definitive goal. Instead, the game is designed to be infinitely playable in short bursts, where goals are randomly generated and the levels are procedurally made. Despite the variety, the game always starts the same, where the player, as Luke Skywalker, arrives at Dagobah in an X-Wing. Goals are then given by Yoda after he is found.

results.title: The House of the Dead for SEGA Saturn
results.material_description: CD-ROM videogame. CD-ROM and manual in Sega Saturn case
results.brief_description:
The House of the Dead is console port of the popular arcade shooter. The player, as agent Thomas Rogan or his partner “G” must rescue Rogan’s fiancée Sophie Richards from the evil scientist Dr. Curien and his undead creations.

This release inherits the same a rail shooter mechanic, where the player is guided through a haunted mansion filled with the undead. The player must shoot any enemies before being attacked while also not shooting any hostages. Items that grant health or different upgrades can also be found. The game also has several points where the player can actively affect the course of the game through their actions. For instance, if a player saves a hostage who is about to be thrown from a bridge, that hostage can open a different route through the game.

This port also contains two extra modes called Saturn Mode and Boss Mode. Saturn mode plays like the arcade game, but offers the player different characters to choose from who have varying attributes like reload time and amount of health. The Boss Mode allows the player to fight one boss of their choosing or all of the game’s four boss monsters consecutively.

results.brief_description:
The official music video for Charli XCX & Troye Sivan - “1999”.

Taken from the third studio album Charli, released in 2019. Charli featured the singles “1999”, “Blame It On Your Love”, “Gone” and “White Mercedes.”

constellations_other.name: Faking history
constellations_other.description: The Great takes a creative approach to its historical characters and settings that is mirrored in its costumes - this war dress might have a classic silhouette, but the grimy pearlescent fabric and striking oxblood detailing is completely modern. Faking history is a time-honoured tradition in film, from historical fiction to propaganda.
